review_title: One of the best side jobs?
pros: Working retail, an annoying and petty manager can make your job such a headache. Target seems able to retain/keep high quality staff members for TL positions. We are asked to do reasonable amounts of work at each shift and scheduling is flexible. I do this job as a second job and I love being able to work as little as 4 hours some weeks. The store is kept clean so that we have a pleasant work environment. My store has a diverse customer base and I like working with a lot of people. We aren’t pressured to buy clothing and accessories from the store to “model” it as some retail jobs expect. The staff discount is better than some other retail jobs.
cons:
More could have been done to protect employees from covid (such as an outdoor dining space for breaks that’s sheltered from rain, and training/culture of keeping 6ft distance even when masked). At times hours are limited so you need to hustle to get everything done or leave things incomplete, but if you stay focused it’s not too much work. For workers needing a lot of hours, this might not be the best job.

Help people who need more hours get more hours by allowing them to work multiple different departments.

After all, that will be what almost all of your time will be spent doing for ~160+ hours a month if you're full time. Ask to watch the first day or two and ask any question you have or have them explain any and all reasoning for their actions. If you can't watch, ask them to show you the end result of a properly done job that you will one day be doing as well. My co-worker was a teenager who was really nice and kind, but he didn't exactly explain everything down to the last detail or he would give out too much information to process too quickly. Not his fault, he's no teacher. It's on you if you don't ask the right questions to be fully prepared to do a good job.

pros:

cons:
Disorganized: I did not feel adequately trained. I had only one shift where I was shown how to do everything. Products were kept behind the bar, in the kitchen, in a closet next to the kitchen, and in the stockroom. Where is the product you need? Who knows!
Dishonest: Management lied to me more often than I could count for the month I worked there. Most were little white lies "he pursued other opportunities" meant he left during his lunch and never came back type thing. But more bafflingly I applied for a nonseasonal position only to be offered a seasonal job. When I called back to turn the work down I was told I definitely was not seasonal it was just for "paperwork" reasons. Cut to a month later and my manager is offering me a permanent position. Shes also asking me to lie and say I wasnt offered permanent work so I dont "hurt the other seasonal workers feelings." I also asked in the interview which shifts I would be expected to work and was promised at least one open, one mid, and one close per week. I only ever worked closes though even at peak hours. So, get absolutely everything in writing.

Convoluted full-time process: I was told first that it was not possible to be full-time. The second that ome could be full-time by splitting shifts between departments ie working 20 hrs cafe shifts and 20 hrs cashiering shifts. I was told third that the hours were not there for me to do so. Finally I was told that this would not qualify me for full-time benefits anyway. Its also apparent theres no room to grow because all these TLs are pulled in from Chicago law schools or whereever instead of fostering company talent.

The employee "discount" is some kind of weird company-tokens deal. I guess this is somehow legal but in order to get access to the employee discount you have to sign up for the target credit card. You can only use that credit card if you want the discount. 

This is more of a pet peeve but in the kitchen you have to use a dull edge rocking pizza cutter because they dont trust you with a real pizza cutter. Ironically, nearly all the equipment in the kitchen will cut you. Every piece of the popcorn machine, the wings on the oven, the crumb trays in the oven, and most absurdly: the tray that holds the dull edged rocking pizza cutter. Please make it make sense. Worst of all, the first aid kit had no bandages. When I told a TL about it she brought two. Thanks, one for me and then one for the next person and then its someone elses problem I guess?

Oh, also there was the MORTIFYING ordeal in orientation where the leader asked us to tell a story of our preconceived judgements against a class of people (I guess for the sake of wokeness?) And he talked about how he, as a black man, used to be very into BLM but then one time a cop let him get away with doing 90 in a 35. Like, what story was anyone supposed to tell here that wouldnt be wildly offensive for the first day?
